27643685.generated_answer:
The potential risk of ZIKV transmission in Australia is currently low due to the absence of competent mosquito species, such as Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, which are known vectors of the virus. However, it is still important to maintain vigilance and conduct regular surveillance as these mosquito species may be introduced through travel or trade, and may establish locally and transmit ZIKV if conditions are suitable. It is also important for public health authorities to be prepared to respond quickly in the event of ZIKV introduction into Australia.  

            References:
            1) https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022215120303703
            2) https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7430109/
            3) https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0962280720304520
            4) https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/
27643685.target_answer: We confirmed Ae. aegypti to be the most likely mosquito vector of ZIKV in Australia, although the restricted distribution of this species will limit the receptive zone to northern Queensland where this species occurs. Importantly, the role in ZIKV transmission of Culex and other Aedes spp. tested will be negligible. Despite being the implicated vector, the relatively high ID50 and need for a high titer disseminated infection in Ae. aegypti suggest that high mosquito population densities will be required to facilitate epidemic ZIKV transmission among the currently immunologically naïve human population in Australia.

Question: How do bacteria respond when exposed to antibiotics?
Context: Antibiotics are drugs that can kill bacteria by disrupting their cellular processes such as DNA transcription and protein synthesis. Bacteria have evolved various mechanisms to respond when they are exposed to these drugs. One way is through efflux pumps, which can expel drugs from their cells, preventing them from reaching their targets. Another mechanism is through the development of resistance mutations within their DNA, which can make them more resistant to the drugs. This process can occur when bacteria are exposed to antibiotics over time.

During prolonged ventricular fibrillation, it is thought that the His bundle may activate faster than the ventricular myocardium (VM). However, the activation rate of the His bundle and VM has not been directly measured during this process. This study measured the activation rate of the His bundle and VM during prolonged ventricular fibrillation (VF) using an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) and bipolar electrograms obtained from the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) and His bundle locations. The results showed that the His bundle activation rate was faster than that of VM during prolonged VF (64±15 vs 40±10 ms, P=0.0004). This observation suggests that activations in the distal ventricular conduction system propagate through the conduction system to activate the His bundle and may drive activation at distant sites. This finding supports the conclusion that the conduction system plays a critical role in the mechanisms of prolonged VF maintenance and may be a target for interventional therapy.
                Context :

25036418.target_answer: During prolonged VF the activation rate of the His bundle is faster than that of the VM. This suggests that the proximal conduction system, like the distal Purkinje system, may be an important driver during long duration VF and may be a target for interventional therapy.
